author: DOUG SMITH Los Angeles Times
title: $750 a month, no questions asked, improved the lives of homeless people
text: LOS ANGELES ‚Äî If 100 homeless people were given $750 per month for a year, no questions asked, what would they spend it on? That question was at the core of a controlled study conducted by a San Francisco-based nonprofit and the USC Suzanne Dworak-Peck School of Social Work. The results were so promising that the researchers decided to publish results after only six months. The answer: food, 36.6%; housing, 19.5%; transportation, 12.7%; clothing, 11.5%; and health care, 6.2%, leaving only 13.6% uncategorized. Those who got the stipend were less likely to be unsheltered after six months and able to meet more of their basic needs than a control group that got no money, and half as likely as the control group to have an episode of being unsheltered. ‚ÄúI felt there was enough interest and the initial findings were compelling enough that it was important to get those results out,‚Äù said Benjamin Henwood, director of the Center for Homelessness, Housing and Health Equity Research at the Dworak-Peck School, who led the study. People are also reading‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúIt may not be earth-shattering that providing money is going to help meet basic needs, but I do think it dispels this myth that people will use money for illicit purposes,‚Äù Henwood said. ‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt finding that in the study.‚Äù About 2% of the total went to alcohol, cigarettes and drug expenses ‚Äî the largest portion of which was cigarettes, Henwood said. The participants submit monthly reports on their spending and are surveyed in more detail quarterly. A follow-up report will be published after participants have received the funds for a full year. But Henwood said the main findings were robust enough that they were unlikely to change. The study arose from Miracle Messages, a San Francisco-based nonprofit that sends volunteers to the streets and shelters to befriend homeless people and try to make connections with the loved ones who lost contact with them. Next founder and chief executive Kevin F. Adler started Miracle Friends, matching homeless people to volunteer phone buddies for weekly calls. That evolved into Miracle Money when volunteers began asking Adler whether it was OK to give their buddies a few dollars. ‚ÄúYou asked me to be a friend to this person, but they don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre going to eat tonight,‚Äù Adler said they would tell him. Adler didn‚Äôt think the volunteers should hand out their own money. But the idea of cash support appealed to him. After a pilot showed promise, Adler got a grant to expand to Los Angeles. He hired two recruiters to canvass homeless shelters. They enlisted more than 200 clients who met the criteria of being at least 18 years old and homeless and expressed interest in having a phone buddy. Rather than just give money away, Adler hoped to document its effect. He teamed up with Henwood, who devised the controlled study. The participants were divided randomly into two groups. One group of 103 received stipends. The others were told they were on a waiting list. After six months, only 12% of those who received funds reported being unsheltered at any time in the prior month, a dramatic decrease from 30% at the outset. Those on the waiting list also reported fewer unsheltered episodes, but by a much smaller margin, from 28% to 23%. The cash recipients also said they were better able to meet their basic needs. On a scale of 1 (completely) to 5 (not at all), they dropped from about 3.75 on average to just over 3.25. The control group did not budge from 3.75. Among those receiving the funds, some found permanent housing, even though the money fell far below average rents in the area, Henwood said. ‚ÄúIt seems like it‚Äôs opening up possibilities in different ways,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey might have a friend or relative that may not be willing to support them completely, but if they have something to contribute that opens up a room.‚Äù In other cases, the money created opportunities, even for people who remained unsheltered. ‚ÄúI spent a lot of the money on food on the go,‚Äù one participant told the researchers. ‚ÄúSimple, cheap things like bean and cheese burritos. I eat on the run while I bike/work for DoorDash. I also bought a membership to REI, so I could get my bike fixed for free.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a single path forward,‚Äù Henwood said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a lot of resourcefulness and creativity.‚Äù 20 facts about homelessness in the US According to HUD, there were 582,462 people experiencing homelessness in the U.S. in January 2022 The U.S. has seen a 0.3% increase in homelessness since 2020 Conversely, the U.S. has seen an 8.6% decrease in homelessness since 2010 Experts from HUD believe that resources from the American Rescue Plan directed toward homelessness assistance lessened the impact of COVID-19 on homelessness The marked increase in rental prices during COVID-19 likely contributed to the recent rise in homelessness HUD's Emergency Rental Assistance program received more than 12 million applications for assistance between August 2021 and January 2022 A greater proportion of people experiencing homelessness were unsheltered in 2022 compared to 2020 40% of all people experiencing homelessness in the U.S. during 2022 were unsheltered Chronic homelessness has increased 15.5% since 2020 Veteran homelessness has decreased by 11% since 2020 and more than 50% since 2010 Family and youth homelessness have both decreased since 2020 50,767 families with children experienced homelessness in 2022 Since 2020, unaccompanied youth homelessness has decreased by 12% 6,398 parenting youth taking care of 7,898 children experienced homelessness in 2022, down 13% since 2020 From 2020 to 2022, the number of people who identified as Hispanic or Latino who experienced homelessness rose by 8% The number of people who identify as Hispanic and experienced unsheltered homelessness in 2022 rose 16% since 2020

author: archyworldyscom
title: Dangerous Hurricane Milton intensifies and approaches Florida with a Category 5 rating
text:
Category 5 Hurricane Milton continues its movement, with winds of 260 kilometers per hour (km/h) and very strong gusts, and is approaching the Tampa Bay area, Florida (United States), according to latest update from the National Hurricane Center Authority (NHC).
Hurricane Milton, defined by the NCH as ‚Äúextremely dangerous‚Äù, has imposed evacuation orders for nearly six million people, according to the American press.
¬´We are at the eleventh hour. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre in an evacuation zone, it‚Äôs time to leave,‚Äù Sheriff Chad Chronister told CNN Wednesday morning.
The same network reported this morning that the outer bands of the hurricane are already being felt in Florida. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve already seen some flooding here early this morning,‚Äù Hillsborough County Sheriff Chad Chronister told CNN.
The latest update from the National Hurricane Center indicates that as of 5 a.m. local time, Hurricane Milton was still a Category 5 hurricane with winds of 160 mph (260k ph) and was about 300 miles (480 km) to the south -west of Tampa.
SEE ALSO We will have drought and rain, but they will be more intense: Dr. Graciela Raga
The Doctor of Atmospheric Sciences addresses the future of climate events in Mexico exclusively with El Siglo de Torre√≥n.
The NHC warned of the power of Hurricane Milton passing over Florida, where ‚Äústorm‚Äù and ‚Äútropical storm‚Äù warnings were activated, phenomena that can occur up to 36 and 48 hours later respectively, according to the Centro agency.
Given the adverse weather situation, the authorities asked citizens who were unable to evacuate to take shelter and protect their properties.
In addition to the winds, the weather service warns that heavy rain could occur Thursday that could cause flooding and river flooding, especially in areas where coastal and continental flooding combine to increase the threat of global flooding.
Authorities ordered the closure of Tampa International Airport and St. Pete-Clearwater International Airport, while those in Orlando and Miami remain open and are monitoring Milton‚Äôs trajectory.
The airport closures will last until Wednesday or Thursday, however passengers have been asked to confirm their connecting flights.
Likewise, the Port of Miami, a major cruise ship docking center, appears shipless and in a tense calm, as can be seen from the company‚Äôs live webcam.
The situation forced the President of the United States, Joe Biden, to postpone his trip to Germany and Angola to be aware of the preparations and the situation that will be created with the arrival of Hurricane Milton, after the passage of the hurricane Helen last September left a toll of nearly 230 deaths when it touched Florida.
Passing close to Mexico, Hurricane Milton, which had dropped to Category 4, although it intensified to Category 5 on its way to Florida, is moving away from the Mexican coast with no reports of deaths or injuries in the main tourist destinations of the Yucatan. , in the Mexican Caribbean.
#Dangerous #Hurricane #Milton #intensifies #approaches #Florida #Category #rating

title: Locura de precios en Ibiza: 20 euros por una copa de vino
text: Que los precios en Ibiza son aptos cada vez m√°s para bolsillos abultados no es ninguna novedad. Sin embargo, siguen d√°ndose casos desconcertantes e inquietantes en cuanto a los altos precios. En este sentido, dos personas se han quedado alucinadas al pedir la cuenta en un establecimiento de Sant Miquel y comprobar que les hab√≠an cobrado 18 euros por una [copa de vino](/etiqueta/copa+de+vino.html?utm_source=Inline-tag&utm_medium=internal) y otros 10 euros por otra copa de otro tipo de [vino](/etiqueta/vino.html?utm_source=Inline-tag&utm_medium=internal). Caray Sant Miquel Cuentas f√°ciles, en hosteler√≠a est√° la norma no escrita de cargarle sobre un 300% a la bebida. Entonces si la botella en cuesti√≥n el establecimiento la compra por 30‚Ç¨ la vender√°n sobre 90‚Ç¨ y si tienen que venderlo a copas pues sobre unos 18‚Ç¨ la copa... No es un precio abusivo teniendo en cuenta el % que cargan algunos restaurantes o discotecas, que por el precio que te venden el cubata pagan 2 botellas... Marketing para mcdonalds despues del marketing para el mercadona Pues a mi si me salen las cuentas, 2 personas que no preguntan cuanto vale ni miran la carta, luego se sienten estafados, calculamos y son dos tontos muy tontos. 56:4=14 as√≠ que casi 20. Para mi son 15 por copa incluido una propina generosa. Ir os de vuelta al cole muchachos. LuiyiA ti te habr√≠an cobrado m√°s por no tener ocho apellidos ibicencos ))) No te cobran por el vino. Te cobran por el ambiente y todo alrededor de ello. Cada uno es libre donde quiere pasar sus vacaciones o vivir. Los precios por regla general est√°n en la carta. Barato. En Madrid o Barcelona te hubiesen cobrado m√°s El figurar cuesta dinero y yo lo veo bien...

author: CNN Newsource
title: Justice Department says new Texas immigration law violates Constitution
text:
Justice Department says new Texas immigration law violates Constitution
By Priscilla Alvarez and Michael Williams, CNN
Washington (CNN) ‚Äî A new law that gives local law enforcement in Texas the authority to arrest migrants ‚Äúviolates the US Constitution,‚Äù the Department of Justice said in a letter to Gov. Greg Abbott on Thursday, threatening to sue unless Abbott backs down from enforcing it.
The letter, obtained by CNN, marks the latest escalation between President Joe Biden and Abbott over the handling of the US-Mexico border.
Earlier this month, Abbott, a Republican, signed into law the measure, known as
 Senate Bill 4, which gives local law enforcement the power to arrest migrants and gives judges the ability to issue orders to remove people from the United States. The White House slammed the law, calling it ‚Äúincredibly extreme.‚Äù It‚Äôs expected to take effect in March.
Principal deputy assistant attorney general Brian Boynton said in his letter to Abbott Thursday that ‚Äúthe United States intends to file suit to enjoin the enforcement of SB 4 unless Texas agrees to refrain from enforcing the law.‚Äù
While the federal government is ‚Äúcommitted to ‚Ä¶ securing the border,‚Äù Boynton wrote, the Texas law is ‚Äúcontrary to these goals.‚Äù
The ongoing surge of migrants at the US-Mexico border has placed immense pressure on local and federal resources. Thursday‚Äôs legal threat follows a DOJ lawsuit against Texas earlier this year over the state‚Äôs use of
 floating barriers in the Rio Grande. That lawsuit is still making its way through the courts.
The enforcement of immigration law is a federal responsibility, and opponents of the Texas measure argue it‚Äôs unconstitutional.
The law has sent ripples of fear throughout the Latino community in Texas, which makes up
40% of the state‚Äôs population. Civil-rights groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union, filed a lawsuit seeking to block the measure.
The Justice Department‚Äôs threat to sue comes on the heels of a
high-levels talks between senior US and Mexican officials this week
Officials from both countries described talks as productive, and Mexican officials are
expected to visit Washington next month to continue the discussions.
